translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Sacred Texts Hinduism Index Previous Next Buy this Book at Amazon.com

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 1. He recites the Va s a hymn 1 , wishing, May everything be in my power.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. They (its verses) are twenty-one 2 , for twenty-one are the parts (the lungs, spleen, &c.) in the belly.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. Then the Ekavi m sa is verily the support of all Stomas, and the belly the support of all food.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. They consist of different metres. Verily, the intestines are confused, some small, some large.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. He recites them with the pra n ava 3 , according to the metre 4 , and according to rule 5 . Verily, the intestines are according to rule, as it were; some shorter, some longer.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. Next comes the Sûdadohas verse. Sûdadohas verily is breath. He joins the joints; with breath.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. After having recited that verse twelve times he

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: leaves it off there. These prâ n as are verily twelvefold, seven in the head, two on the breast, three below. In these twelve places the prâ n as are contained, there they are perfect. Therefore he leaves it off there 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. The hymn indrâgnî yuva m su nah (Rv. VIII, 40) forms the two thighs (of the bird) belonging to Indra and Agni, the two supports with broad bones.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. These (verses) consist of six feet, so that they may stand firm. Man stands firm on two feet, animals on four. He thus places man (the sacrificer), standing on two feet, among four-footed cattle.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. The second verse has seven feet, and he makes it into a Gâyatrî and Anush t ubh. Gâyatrî is Brahman, Anush t ubh is speech; and he thus puts together speech with Brahman.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 11. He recites a Trish t ubh at the end. Trish t ubh is strength, and thus does he come round animals by strength. Therefore animals come near where there is strength (of command, &c.); they come to be roused and to rise up, (they obey the commands of a strong shepherd.)

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 193:1 Having recited the verses which form the body, neck, head, wings, and tail of the bird, also the food intended for the bird, he now describes the Va s a hymn, i.e. the hymn composed by Va s a, Rv. VIII, 46. That hymn takes the place of the stomach which receives the food intended for the bird. Cf. Ait. Âr. V, 2, 5. In I, 5, 2, 4 it is called a Nivid.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 193:2 Verses 1-20 of the Vasa hymn, and one Sûdadohas.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 193:3 Pra n âvam means 'with pra n ava,' i.e. inserting Om in the proper places.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 193:4 According as the metres of the different verses are fixed by S aunaka, Ait. Âr. V, 2, 5, who says that verse 15 is Dvipadâ, and that the last four words, nûnam atha, form an Ekapadâ.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 193:5 According to rule, i.e. so that they should come right as Â s valâyana has prescribed the recitation of Dvipadâ and Ekapadâ verses. In a Dvipadâ there should be a stop after the first foot, and Om at the end o f the second. Ira an Ekapadâ there should be Om at the beginning and at the end.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Next: I, 5, 2
